PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The Government requested ADB for assistance in financing the proposed Shanxi Energy 
Efficiency  and  Environment  Improvement  Project.  However,  SPG  informed  ADB  that  the 
feasibility study and environment assessment of the proposed subprojects have not yet been 
finalized,  thus  limited  information  is  available  at  the  moment.  This  situation  presents  an 
opportunity for fielding selected experts to assist the implementing agencies of subprojects in 
improving the project design and familiarizing with ADB’s requirements and procedures. A 
project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is required to conduct the due diligence on several 
aspects of the proposed loan (para. 9 of main text).

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $650,000 equivalent. It is proposed that ADB 
finance $550,000 equivalent on a grant basis from the TA special fund-Others. The Government 
will provide the balance of local costs, equivalent to $100,000, to cover in-kind counterpart costs 
and services for counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative support services, and 
local (city) transport and logistics costs. The detailed cost estimate is in Table A5.2. The 
government was advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing 
project.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  An  early  start  in  the  implementation  of  the  subprojects  is  critical  to  ensure  that 
implementation activities are started during the non-heating season in 2013. Thus, in order to 
meet  this  requirement,  immediate  start  of  data  collection  and  preliminary  assessment  of

3 
proposed subprojects’ documents will help identify, at an early stage, critical issues to be 
investigated and ensure that good quality project documentation necessary to meet the loan 
processing schedule is produced. The TA will thus be implemented in two stages, Part 1 (data 
gathering and preliminary assessment) and Part 2 (detailed assessment). Part 1 can commence 
immediately while the consultant selection process for Part 2 is still ongoing. For Part 1, four 
individual national consultants (total of 8 person-months) will be recruited by ADB in accordance 
with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). For Part 2, 
a consulting firm will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) through quality- and cost-based selection 
method (with a quality-cost ratio of 80:20) using simplified technical proposal. Part 2 will require 
a total of 10.5 person-months of international and 24 person-months of national consulting 
services.  The  required  positions  and  person-months  are  indicated  in  Table  A5.3.  The 
procurement  of  equipment  by  consultants,  under  the  TA,  will  follow  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). These equipment shall be turned over to the 
executing agency upon TA completion. Disbursement under the TA will be done in accordance 
with the ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time).

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  The executing agency will be the SPG. The implementing agencies will be the municipal 
government of each subprojects or the heating and gas supply companies supported by the

4 
project management office (PMO)1 under the SPG to coordinate and communicate with relevant 
government agencies and ADB. The executing agency and the implementing agencies will 
provide support to the consultants, including (i) arranging meetings with relevant government 
agencies and industries; (ii) providing access to all data permitted by the PRC law, including 
documents,  reports,  accounts,  drawings  and  maps,  and  permission  to  enter  offices,  as 
appropriate and necessary, to undertake the work, (iii) a suitably furnished office with utilities 
and  telecommunication  access,  and  (iv)  city-level  transport  for  consultants.  Costs  for  the 
conduct of various workshops/ seminars/ conferences and surveys will be administered by the 
consulting firm.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Part 1 
 
1.  The outline terms of references for Part 1 of the project preparatory TA consultants are 
described in paras. 2 to 5. 
 
2.  Heating Engineer (national, 2 person-months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Visit each subproject site to assess the status of preparation and readiness of the 
proposed subproject, and outline the estimated period for approval by relevant 
government authorities. 
(ii)  Review feasibility reports and other relevant documents to (a) assess technical 
soundness,  (b)  identify  technical  risks,  and  (c)  recommend  areas  for 
improvement of the project design.  
(iii)  Estimate preliminary heating demand of each subproject.  
(iv)  Assess the potential energy efficiency improvements from each subproject. 
(v)  Analyze demand-side (residential and commercial buildings) energy conservation 
measures  including  technical,  regulatory,  building  code,  and  heating  pricing 
aspects together with the Sector Specialist. 
(vi)  Conduct  comparative  cost  analysis  and  and  describe  technology  employed 
between coal-based district heating system and renewable based district heating 
(solar, wind, biomass, or heat pump) and justify why or why not coal-based district 
heating is the most appropriate technology in the project area.  
(vii)  Coordinate with the other specialists in the preparation of a preliminary project 
assessment report and prepare the technical sections of the report. 
 
3.  Environment Specialist (national, 2 person-months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Visit each subproject site and review the draft environmental impact assessment 
(EIA) reports to assess its completeness and estimated period for approval by 
relevant government authorities;  
(ii)  Collect  preliminary  data  on  land  acquisition,  housing  demolition,  number  of 
affected people, and compensation rate.  
(iii)  Identify any major risks associated with environmental related issues and make 
preliminary  assessment  whether  adequate  mitigation  measures  have  been 
proposed. 
(iv)  Perform a preliminary assessment of the environmental benefits from project 
implementation, including (a) energy efficiency improvements, (b) reductions in 
air emissions, and (c) other environmental benefits.  
(v)  Estimate the air emission reductions of main pollutants as a result of each central 
heating subproject based on the number of boilers to be removed within the 
service areas of each subproject. Perform similar analysis for the gas project. 
(vi)  Review  the  costs  of  the  proposed  environmental  mitigation  measures  and 
implementation of the environmental monitoring plan. 
(vii)  Initially categorize possible environmental classification based on the review of 
the draft EIAs for each subproject. 
(viii)  Prepare the environmental section of the preliminary project assessment report. 
 
4.  Financial Specialist (national, 2 person-months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Visit  all  implementing  agencies  to  (a)  assess  the  organizational  structure 
including ownership structure of private sector, (b) assess financial management

6 
capacity  and  internal  controls,  and  (c)  recommend  required  institutional 
strengthening and capacity building. 
(ii)  Review  the  audited  and  unaudited  financial  statements  of  the  implementing 
agencies for the past 4 years to assess: (a) historical financial performance, (b) 
heating tariffs, (c) capital structure, and (d) sufficient generation of internal funds 
to support sustainability of ongoing operations (i.e., the ability to service existing 
debts and to finance a reasonable proportion of capital expenditures). 
(iii)  Conduct preliminary financial management assessment. 
(iv)  Conduct  a  preliminary  financial  analysis  of  all  subprojects  and  prepare 
preliminary projected financial statements (balance sheet, income statement, and 
statement of cash flows) for the next 10 years).  
(v)  Prepare the financial section of the preliminary project assessment report. 
 
5.  Sector Specialist (national, 2.0 person-months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Provide general macro and sector information, including energy production and 
consumption  by  sector,  energy  efficiency,  and  heating/gas  production  and 
consumption by sector for the PRC and Shanxi province. Analyze the sectoral 
and policy context of the proposed project. 
(ii)  Obtain  information  on  the  provincial  policy  and  status  of  implementation  of 
renewable energy program (e.g., solar, wind, biomass, coal bed and coal mine 
methane gas or heat pump), including government plan, if any, to switch heating 
source from coal to renewables. Collect information on total heating area served by 
renewable energy disaggregated by energy source. 
(iii)  Assess the current status and challenges of the heating and gas sectors in the 
People's Republic of China (PRC) and Shanxi province. 
(iv)  Assess policies and reform program, and status of enforcement on heating and 
gas subsectors with emphasis on (a) tariff system and affordability analysis, (b) 
billing and collection, and (c) regulations and policies on energy conservation and 
efficiency  improvement  including  building  energy  efficiency  measures  and 
demand side management, (d) assistance program for the poor, and (e) private 
sector participation. Develop appropriate recommendations. 
(v)  Obtain  city-specific heating and gas supply/demand status in the project cities. 
(vi)  Review  the  heating/gas  tariff  structures  and  heating/gas  tariff  adjustment 
procedures in Shanxi province and in each of the project cities. Discuss with 
relevant government agencies on their plans to reform heating/gas tariff system 
and the implementation plan for approved reforms. 
(vii)  Discuss with the implementing agencies on the collection of heating/gas tariffs, 
collection rates and measures taken or to be taken to increase the collection 
rates. 
(viii)  Assess affordability issues related to heating/gas supply for the poor; review the 
current practices to help reduce the burden of the poor on heating/gas tariffs; 
recommend pro-poor activities that could be included in the project and would 
directly benefit the poor in the project cities. 
(ix)  Analyze demand-side (residential and commercial buildings) energy conservation 
measures  including  technical,  regulatory,  building  code,  and  heating  pricing 
aspects together with the heating engineer. 
(x)  Provide an independent assessment of the short-term (3 years) and long-term 
(system planning period) demand forecasts that take into account historical trends, 
structural changes, efficiency improvement, energy prices, gross domestic product 
growth, investment distribution and growth, and other important factors affecting 
energy, heating demand and gas demand in Shanxi province.

7 
(xi)  Analyze government policies that may have significant impact on the demand and 
supply  of  energy.  Provide  a  detailed  discussion  of  the  assumptions  and 
methodology used in demand forecasting.  
(xii)  Discuss the possibilities for corporatization of district heating companies. Identify 
the barriers.  
(xiii)  Prepare a report and prepare the analysis section for the heating and gas sectors 
of the project due diligence report. 
 
B.   Part 2 
 
6.  The outline terms of references for the Part 2 of project preparatory TA consultants are 
described in paras. 7 to 13. 
 
7.  Heating Engineer/Team Leader (international, 5 person-months; national, 5 person 
months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Take  project  team  leadership  and  coordinate  with  all  other  experts  on  the 
assignment to ensure quality of work. The national expert will act as the team 
leader among the national consultants and will assist the international expert in 
performing all tasks. 
(ii)  Be responsible for the overall management of the project and liaise with ADB and 
the executing agency during the implementation of the project preparatory TA. 
(iii)  Evaluate technical issues for each subproject by reviewing background data and 
feasibility reports for each subproject, and if appropriate, provide suggestions for 
improvement of the project design. 
(iv)  Assess the physical resources, including heat capacity, heat production, and 
design concepts. Determine and provide the full technical justification for the 
subprojects and compare with possible alternatives. 
(v)  Compare  the  internationally  available  best  technologies  in  terms  of  energy 
efficiency  and  emission  reduction,  identify  pros  and  cons  for  best  available 
technologies, and propose locally appropriate technology in the project design. 
(vi)  Assess possibility of combined heat and power plants for heat supply source. 
(vii)  Identify the likely technical and other risks facing the various aspects of each 
subproject,  and  evaluate  the  viability  of  the  project  under  these  risks. 
Recommend mitigating measures. 
(viii)  Review  sector  analysis  and  identify  gaps.  Review  heating/gas  demand 
projections and assess the assumptions for the projections in conjunction with 
the Financial Specialist and Economist. 
(ix)  Review calculations done by the Environment Specialist on the energy efficiency 
improvements, avoided annual coal consumption, and avoided annual emission 
(green house gasses and the other air pollutants) and analyze/compare with the 
province’s heating and gas sectors province’s energy efficiency, and emission 
reduction targets. 
(x)  In coordination with other experts prepare implementation plan, procurement 
plan, and financing packages of each subprojects, including labor retrenchment 
plan,  if  necessary.  Develop  clear  project  implementation  plan  as  well  as 
operations/management/maintenance  arrangements  and  identify  responsible 
parties  (a  sample  of  how  this  was  in  another  ADB  project  is  available  for 
reference). 
(xi)  With inputs from the Financial and the Procurement Specialists, prepare a project 
administration  manual  in  coordination  with  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies.

8 
(xii)  Review assessment made by the Economist on the private sector participation in 
the heating and gas sectors and the attendant barriers and opportunities. 
(xiii)  Guide and coordinate with other specialists in the preparation of a project due 
diligence report and prepare the technical sections of the report. 
(xiv)  Lead and ensure the preparation of all required reports in ADB formats and 
quality standards. 
(xv)  Coordinate  with  ADB,  executing/implementing  agencies  and  relevant 
stakeholders and conduct workshops and training. 
 
8.  Environment Specialist (international, 3 person-months; national, 4 person-months) 
will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Review the environmental impact assessment (EIA) reports prepared by local 
EIA institutes for each subproject and make sure that all EIA reports meet ADB 
requirements,  particularly  the  new  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  2009, 
which became effective on 20 January 2010.  
(ii)  Evaluate  environmental  impacts  of  each  subproject,  and  recommend 
environmentally  friendly  technologies  for  the  design  and  construction,  which 
emphasizes on (a) biodiversity conservation, (b) public health and safety, (c) 
physical  cultural  resources,  (d)  pollution  prevention  and  abatement,  and  (e) 
climate change mitigation including potential use of clean energy source, and 
ensure that those aspects are documented and incorporated in the EIA reports.  
(iii)  Based on review of the EIAs, assist the executing and implementing agencies in 
preparing the consolidated project EIA report in the format required by ADB.  
(iv)  Assess  the  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  on 
environmental  assessment,  management,  and  monitoring,  and  recommend 
required  measures  for  capacity  building;  identify  areas  for  improvement  and 
training needs with respect to the environmental safeguard under the project and 
based on this, prepare materials and conduct the training workshop to the staff of 
the  executing  agency,  implementing  agency  and  other  stockholders  on 
environmental management and safeguard.  
(v)  Assist the executing agency and EIA institutes prepare a sound environment 
management plan (EMP), and establish a public grievance mechanism in the EIA 
reports. Determine monitoring requirements and design monitoring forms. 
(vi)  Identify environmental risks and propose a set of mitigating measures. 
(vii)  Review the cost implications of the proposed environmental mitigation measures 
and implementation of the EMP. 
(viii)  Assist  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agencies  in  stakeholders 
participation and consultation during preparation of EIA/consolidated EIA and 
disclosure of relevant information.  
(ix)  Establish environmental baseline indicators and performance targets.  
(x)  Together with the Heating Engineer, assess and quantify environment benefits 
such as energy efficiency improvements, GHG emission reduction, and other 
associated environmental benefits.  
(xi)  Prepare list of activities and budget requirements for independent environment 
monitoring and evaluation during project implementation.  
 
9.  Social Safeguards Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 3 person-
months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Visit all subproject sites and assess the land acquisition impact of all subprojects 
and  prepare  land  acquisition  plan,  if  required,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement 2009.

9 
(ii)  Assess  the  labor  retrenchment  issue  of  all  subprojects  and  prepare  a  labor 
retrenchment  plan,  if  necessary,  and  together  with  the  Financial  Specialist, 
determine cost implications. 
(iii)  Determine  number  of  project  beneficiaries  (e.g.,  households,  commercial, 
industrial,  etc.)  and  assess  project  impacts.  Collect  basic  socio-economic 
indicators such as (a) total population and households, (b) total female headed 
households, (c) poverty ratio, (d) major industries and sources of income, (e) 
incidence  of  carbon  monoxide  poisoning  and  respiratory  diseases),  and  (f) 
number of heating beneficiaries by subprojects disaggregated by gender and 
newly  and  existing  connected  households,  in  all  subproject  areas  and  the 
province. Conduct comparative analysis by using such data. 
(iv)  Assess the willingness-to-pay for heating and gas supply by consumers in the 
project area in consultation with the Economist, based on sample survey of energy 
consumed, price paid by households, and household income. 
(v)  Assist the Economist in assessing affordability issues related to heating and gas 
supply for the poor; review the current practices to help reduce the burden of the 
poor  on  heating  and  gas  tariff;  recommend  pro-poor  activities  that  could  be 
included in the project and would directly benefit the poor in the project cities. 
(vi)  Assess  the  project’s  impact  on  health  including  avoided  carbon  monoxide 
poisoning and respiratory diseases by using coal stove, paying attention to the 
gender difference.. 
(vii)  Assess the poverty reduction and social benefit for the district heating and CMM 
gas distribution projects and identify special measures to benefit the poor. 
(viii)  Confirm  that  the  project  does  not  have  impact  on  ethnic  minorities. 
Check/validate presence/absence of Indigenous Peoples in the project area and 
determine if the project will affect them positively or adversely. 
(ix)  Examine  impacts  of  the  project  to  female-headed  households  (FHH),  e.g., 
determine proportion of FHHs in the project area and how gender-differentiated 
impacts will be addressed to ensure equality of access to heating for FHHs. 
 
10.  Gas Distribution Engineer (international, 1.0 person-months; national, 2.0 person-
months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare a brief summary of the current status of the gas subsector in Shanxi 
province and in the project city. Review background data and the feasibility study 
report prepared for the CMM gas subproject and, if applicable, present specific 
suggestions for improvement and finalization of project design.  
(ii)  Review demand projections and validate the technical assumptions made in the 
feasibility  study  report.  Carry  out  least-cost  assessment  of  the  proposed 
subproject and confirm that the design for the CMM gas component is part of the 
least-cost expansion plan. 
(iii)  Determine  and  provide  the  full  technical  justification  for  the  subproject  and 
compare with possible alternatives. 
(iv)  Assess the technical and institutional capacity of the implementing agency for the 
gas  distribution  subproject  and  recommend,  where  required,  changes  to  the 
implementing  agency’s  institutional  structures  to  improve  technical  and 
institutional implementation capacity. Identify technical training needs for the IA, 
and perform training need assessments for improving technical and institutional 
capacity. 
(v)  Assess the likely technical risks facing the various aspects of the gas distribution 
subproject, and work closely with the Financial Specialist to carry out sensitivity 
analysis to check the viability of the subproject.

10 
(vi)  Assess CMM gas source and gas supply risk, and suggest the risk mitigating 
measures. Determine contractual mechanisms to ensure supply (e.g. take-or-pay 
contracts).  Examine  existing  CMM  supply  arrangements  in  Shanxi  and 
recommend workable options for the project. 
(vii)  Work with the Environmental Specialists to evaluate and quantify environmental 
benefits of utilizing CMM gas instead of coal. 
 
11.  Financial Specialist (national, 3 person-months) will perform the following tasks:  
(i)  Evaluate  the  organizational  structure  and  financial  department  of  the 
implementing agencies. 
(ii)  Assess  the  financial  management  capabilities  and  internal  controls  of  the 
implementing  agencies,1  and  make  recommendations  for  institutional 
strengthening and capacity building needed during the project preparatory TA 
phase  and  during  the  project  implementation  period.  Prepare  a  financial 
management assessment report. 
(iii)  Based on the results of the financial management assessment, design funds flow 
and disbursement arrangements (including any necessary capacity building on 
financial management and disbursement procedures). 
(iv)  Conduct  a  review  of  the  audited  and  unaudited  financial  statements  of  the 
implementing agencies for the past 4 years to assess: (a) historical financial 
performance, (b) heating and gas tariffs, (c) capital structure, and (d) sufficient 
generation of internal funds to support sustainability of ongoing operations (e.g., 
the ability to service existing debts and to finance a reasonable proportion of 
capital expenditures). 
(v)  Carry-out financial analysis2 of all subprojects, including the determination of the 
financial  internal  rates  of  return  and  weighted  average  cost  of  capital,  and 
conduct sensitivity analyses for various possible scenarios. Prepare projected 
financial statements (balance sheet, income statement, and statement of cash 
flows) for the next 10 years. 
(vi)  Assess sustainability of the operations of the subproject companies given the 
level of existing tariffs. Perform an analysis of the required level of tariff and 
necessary financial action plan to ensure sustainability.  
(vii)  Coordinate  with  other  experts  and  determine  cost  implications  of  labor 
retrenchment program, if needed.

(viii)  Prepare the financial section of the project due diligence report and recommend 
appropriate financial loan covenants. 
(ix)  Prepare  financial  related  sections  of  the  project  administration  manual  in 
coordination with the executing and implementing agencies. 
 
12.  Economist (national, 3 person-months) will perform the following tasks:  
(i)  Review  the  output  of  the  Sector  Specialist  and  obtain  additional  data,  as 
necessary. Perform the economic analysis for the proposed project/subprojects, 
guided by the ADB Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects: specifically 
including (a) heating and gas sector demand analysis, (b) least-cost and equalizing 
discount  rate  analysis,  (c) economic  viability  analysis,  and  (d)  risk  analysis. 
Discuss alternative methodologies for carrying-out the economic analysis.  
(ii)  Assess the willingness-to-pay for heating and gas sectors, by consumers, in the 
project  area  in  consultation  with  the  Social  Safeguards  Specialist,  based  on 
sample survey of energy consumed, price paid by households, and household 
income.  
(iii)  Incorporate  into  the  economic  analysis  an  economic  quantification  of 
environmental  impacts  following  ADB’s  Economic  Valuation  of  Environmental 
Impacts: A Workbook (1996), and Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). 
(iv)  Provide quantitative and qualitative benefits of the proposed project and each of its 
components. 
(v)  Assess potential mechanisms to address affordability issues (e.g., subsidies for 
poverty households or waiver connection charges). 
(vi)  Coordinate  with  other  experts  and  determine  cost  implications  of  labor 
retrenchment program. 
(vii)  Review  and  assess  the  institutional  arrangements  and  the  current  status  of 
private sector participation in the heating and gas sectors. Assess the potentials 
for privatization of district heating and gas distribution companies. 
 
13.   Procurement Specialist (national, 4 person-months) will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Prepare indicative procurement plan and financing plan in coordination with the 
Heating Engineer.  
(ii)  Conduct procurement capacity assessment of the executing agency and the 
implementing agencies and develop appropriate recommendations. 
(iii)  Based on the result of the capacity assessment, design and provide training to 
the  implementing  agencies  and  selected  procurement  agencies  on  ADB’s 
procurement procedures and guidelines and bidding document preparation, in 
conjunction with the ADB’s resident mission. 
(iv)  Review  the  initial  bidding  documents  prepared  by  each  of  the  implementing 
agencies or design institutes and revise them accordingly to meet ADB standards 
and requirements. Translate these six bidding documents into English for ADB’s 
review. 
(v)  Prepare procurement related sections of the project administration manual in 
coordination with the executing and implementing agencies. 
 
C.  Reports 
 
14.  The consultant shall submit the following reports to ADB and to the Government in both 
English and Chinese:

12 
  Part 1:  
  Individual expert’s report to be submitted within 4 months from commencement 
of the services. 
 
Part 2: 
(i)  Inception report. To be submitted within 4 weeks after the commencement of the 
services.  The  report  includes  a  detailed  work  program  plus  any  major 
inconsistencies in the terms of reference, staffing problems or deficiencies in the 
government’s assistance.  
(ii)  Interim report. To be submitted within 4 months after the commencement of the 
services.  The  report  includes  a preliminary  result  of  activities,  updated  work 
program, and any issues and concerns. 
(iii)  Draft final report. To be submitted within 7 months after the commencement of 
the services. Upon submission of the draft final report, a final workshop will be 
held, attended by relevant stakeholders, to get feedback on the report. 
(iv)  Final report. To be submitted within 2 months after receipt of comments from 
ADB and the Government on the draft final report. The final report shall take into 
consideration the comments of ADB and the Government. A maximum of 10 
pages summary report should be included in the final report.
